examples.0: Does not have a clear understanding of Cherwell metrics and how they can be used to gauge effectiveness.
examples.1: Has a basic understanding of what Cherwell metrics mean, but may need assistance to implement improvements.
examples.2: Has detailed knowledge of what the Cherwell metrics mean and uses it to improve.
examples.3: Has detailed knowledge of what the Cherwell metrics mean and uses it to help self and others grow.

S2.competency: Comfortably navigates and effectively uses Cherwell.

examples.0: Has no experience in Cherwell.
examples.1: Has basic knowledge and access to Cherwell.
examples.2: Has detailed knowledge of Cherwell and navigates comfortably with advanced settings, such as One Steps.
examples.3: Has detailed knowledge of Cherwell, navigates comfortably and evangelizes tips with their team.

S3.competency: Understands how to use Active Directory and MyAccess to fulfill access requests.

examples.0: Does not have a clear understanding of how to use Active Directory and MyAccess for permissions.
examples.1: Has a basic understanding of AD and MyAccess.
examples.2: Has an advanced understanding of access and proactively takes appropriate action.
examples.3: Has an advanced understanding of access, makes decisions for complex requests, and mentors team members.

S4.competency: Knows the difference between hardware and software issues.

examples.0: Does not know how to determine whether the source of an issue is hardware or software.
examples.1: Identifies the source of the issue correctly.
examples.2: Proactively identifies the source of the issue and leverages KIP to find a solution.
examples.3: Proactively identifies the source of the issue, leverages KIP to find a solution, and shares the knowledge with the team.

examples.0: Does not participate in a SME role.
examples.1: Maintains a SME role.
examples.2: Consistently engages and supports team members in multiple SME roles.
examples.3: Consistently engages and supports in multiple SME roles and/or is a captain of a SME role.

S6.competency: Understands the business support applications and is able to engage and provide a solution.

examples.0: Has no understanding of business support applications.
examples.1: Leverages KIP and other resources to identify and understand issues, but may need assistance in resolving.
examples.2: Engages and takes action to independently resolve problems with business support applications.
examples.3: Has a strong understanding and knowledge of business applications. Has a relationship with members from other business support applications to help improve processes for the team and area.

T1.competency: Participates in activities such as volunteering, IT Fun Factory, The Guy events, and other things that promote team unity and culture.

examples.0: Does not participate in these activities.
examples.1: Participates in the minimally suggested activities.
examples.2: Consistently participates in and promotes activities to the team.
examples.3: Consistently participates in, promotes, and orchestrates activities for the team.

T2.competency: Coaches, develops, and mentors other team members.

examples.0: Does not participate in developing other team members.
examples.1: Trains team members, and answers questions when asked.
examples.2: Proactively mentors and develops team members.
examples.3: Is the go-to person to develop other team members and creates training content.

T3.competency: Contributes to KIP to help expand the knowledge of the team.

examples.0: Does not contribute to KIP.
examples.1: Often submits articles to KIP utilizing the standards defined by the team.
examples.2: Consistently submits articles to KIP utilizing the standards defined by the team.
examples.3: Consistently submits articles, is an Editor or Admin in KIP, and evangelizes KIP to the rest of the team.

T4.competency: Supports the team when ticket volume is high and/or when staffing is low.

examples.0: Does not support the team or respond when there is an IC Red notification or a need for a cover.
examples.1: Responds and supports the team when there is an IC Red or need for a cover.
examples.2: Consistently and proactively supports the team during an IC Red or cover.
examples.3: Consistently and proactively identifies the need for IC Red, supports team members, and looks for team members who need help.

B1.competency: Escalates tickets to the proper team when The Guy Tech cannot resolve the ticket.

examples.0: Does not understand which avenue to escalate tickets to.
examples.1: Escalates tickets to the correct team.
examples.2: Consistently escalates tickets to the correct team.
examples.3: Consistently escalates tickets to the correct team, with an expert understanding of why those tickets need to get esclated, and what happens to the ticket after escalation.

B2.competency: Takes action to support the team when an outage occurs.

examples.0: Does not respond when there are outages or requires frequent guidance.
examples.1: Responds to outages and takes steps to support when asked.
examples.2: Consistently takes the conn on responding to outages.
examples.3: Consistently takes the conn on reacting to outages, communicating to the appropriate teams about the outage, and communicates the 90k.

B3.competency: Has an understanding of the roles and teams in the company that they support.

examples.0: Does not show a knowledge of other teams in the business.
examples.1: Understands some of the other roles in the business.
examples.2: Understands the other roles of teams in the business and knows how it effects the role of The Guy.
examples.3: Has an expert understanding of the other roles of teams in the business and how it affects their role and the business as a whole and mentors team members.

B4.competency: Knows when to grant access to team members based on role function.

examples.0: Does not show an understanding of what access team members should have.
examples.1: Knows generally what access team members should have, and utilizes MyAccess Comparer or other resources to determine correct access.
examples.2: Has a deep understanding of what access a team member should have and how it affects that team member's role.
examples.3: Has an expert understanding of access, how it affects the team members role and helps with the processes of granting access.

C1.competency: Identifies and investigates outage causes and underlying problems that create incident tickets.

examples.0: Does not work past the base level resolution of issues.
examples.1: Identifies problems in process/issues, but may need assistance in escalating them.
examples.2: Proactively identifies underlying problems and collaborates with other teams to identify a solution.
examples.3: Proactively identifies underlying problems and takes the conn on notifying business partners throughout the process.

C2.competency: Maintains communication on issues or requests submitted to The Guy Tech.

examples.0: Routinely has large quantity, excessive dates of tickets that have not been updated.
examples.1: Meets expectations for ticket follow ups, maintains the less than 24 hours standard for every ticket.
examples.2: Consistently follows up with team members as soon as the updates occur.
examples.3: Consistently reaches out to escalating teams for updates daily and provides updates to the team member regardless of status.

C3.competency: Has an awareness and communicates status of current outages.

examples.0: Limited to no awareness of 90k messages.
examples.1: Familiar with current outage information, and can give general information to the business when requested.
examples.2: Stays aware and acts on outage updates until resolution. Is familiar with details and can communicate effectively to the business regarding impact.
examples.3: Consistently provides awareness to the team and proactively communicates to business areas on outage updates.

C4.competency: Actively monitors and contributes in The Guy Tech Teams chat.

examples.0: Doesn't respond in Teams or keep it open.
examples.1: Communicates in Teams when reached out to directly, follows required groups.
examples.2: Responds to questions and contributes in multiple groups/channels.
examples.3: Consistently responds and contributes in multiple groups/channels, redistributes information through Teams, advocates for others to use.

P1.competency: Completes expected amount of Cherwell tickets.

examples.0: Does not complete the expected amount of tickets per month.
examples.1: Completes the minimum amount of tickets per month.
examples.2: Consistently exceeds the expected amount of tickets per month.
examples.3: Consistently exceeds the expected amount of tickets per month and provides additional support to projects and the team.

P2.competency: Proficient in troubleshooting to resolve issues.

examples.0: Does not consistently resolve issues without assistance.
examples.1: Consistently resolves issues, and uses KIP to answer questions.
examples.2: Consistently resolves basic and complex issues with little or no research time needed.
examples.3: Effectively resolves issues and adds to troubleshooting knowledge base (KIP)

P3.competency: Supports team member requests using chat, email, and phone communication.

examples.0: Cannot function effectively in one or many methods of communication.
examples.1: Meets expectations in all methods of communication.
examples.2: Consistently and independently resolves issues in any communication method.
examples.3: Performs at an expert level in multiple communication mediums simultaneously and mentors and assists fellow team members.

P4.competency: Gathers and documents troubleshooting steps for resolution.

examples.0: Does not gather required information without assistance or follow up.
examples.1: Gathers minimum amount of information to troubleshoot.
examples.2: Consistently obtains screen shots, detailed notes, and examples of issue.
examples.3: Consistently researches, provides additional clarity and suggestions when escalating a ticket to another team and coordinates documentation and training for the team.
